'Cerium(IV) oxide', also known as 'ceric oxide', 'ceria', 'cerium oxide' or
'cerium dioxide', is an oxide of the rare earth metal cerium. It is a pale yellow-
white powder with the chemical formula CeO 2.

Cerium(IV) oxide is formed by the calcination of cerium oxalate or cerium
hydroxide.

Powdered ceria is slightly hygroscopic and will also absorb a small amount of
carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Rovert David Green [http://etd.ohiolink.edu/send-
pdf.cgi/Green%20Robert%20David.pdf?case1232574534 Carbon dioxide reduction on
gadolinium-doped ceria cathodes]. PhD Thesis. Department of Chemical
Engineering, CASE Western Reserve University. May, 2009

Cerium also forms cerium(III) oxide, Ce 2O 3, but
CeO 2 is the most stable phase at room temperature and under
atmospheric conditions.
